facts.text: This is an appeal with special leave from an order dated May 29, 1956, passed by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal Calcutta Bench, Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal with special leave from an order dated May 29, 1956, passed by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal  Calcutta Bench , Calcutta, disallowing the assessees claim for deducting a sum of Rs. 1, 24, 199 odd under the provisions of section 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Tribunal disallowed assessee's claim for deducting Rs. 1,24,199 under section 10(2)(xv) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922

anchor.surface_text: disallowing the assessees claim for deducting a sum of Rs. 1, 24, 199 odd under the provisions of section 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922. The assessee, appellant before us, is a public limited companypany with its registered office in Calcutta.

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company with registered office in Calcutta

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, appellant before us, is a public limited companypany with its registered office in Calcutta. Its principal business is the manufacture of aluminium ingots, sheets circles, aluminium alloys, etc., and production of various aluminium or alloy products.

facts.text: Assessee's principal business is manufacture of aluminium ingots, sheets circles, aluminium alloys, and production of various aluminium or alloy products

anchor.surface_text: Its principal business is the manufacture of aluminium ingots, sheets circles, aluminium alloys, etc., and production of various aluminium or alloy products. Under a deed of agreement dated January 31, 1947, made with the appellant the Aluminium Laboratories Ltd., Montreal, Canada,

facts.text: Deed of agreement dated January 31, 1947 made with Aluminium Laboratories Ltd., Montreal, Canada

anchor.surface_text: Under a deed of agreement dated January 31, 1947, made with the appellant the Aluminium Laboratories Ltd., Montreal, Canada, a foreign companypany, having laboratories and research facilities in Canada and the United Kingdom agreed in companysideration of an annual retainer fee to provide regularly and diligently technical and engineering informations,

facts.text: Foreign company Aluminium Laboratories Ltd. has laboratories and research facilities in Canada and the United Kingdom

anchor.surface_text: a foreign companypany, having laboratories and research facilities in Canada and the United Kingdom agreed in companysideration of an annual retainer fee to provide regularly and diligently technical and engineering informations, advice and service, etc., to the appellant on the basis of research carried on in their laboratories.

facts.text: Foreign company agreed to provide technical and engineering informations, advice and service for annual retainer fee payable at Montreal in Canadian dollars

anchor.surface_text: having laboratories and research facilities in Canada and the United Kingdom agreed in companysideration of an annual retainer fee to provide regularly and diligently technical and engineering informations, advice and service, etc., to the appellant on the basis of research carried on in their laboratories. The case of the appellant was that such technical and engineering informations, etc., were essential for the maintenance of the standard of its products on a par with those of other companypetitors in the field. The remuneration which the foreign companypany had to be paid was payable at Montreal in Canadian dollars.

facts.text: Appellant's case: technical informations essential for maintenance of product standards

anchor.surface_text: The case of the appellant was that such technical and engineering informations, etc., were essential for the maintenance of the standard of its products on a par with those of other companypetitors in the field.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held tax deduction liability under sections 18(3A) and 18(3B) arises at actual payment, not crediting, and set aside ITO order

anchor.surface_text: Fo There was an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner who held that though the sums payable to the foreign companypany were chargeable to income- tax, the liability to deduct and pay tax under section 18 3A  and 18 3B  arose number when the sums were credited to the account of the foreign companypany but at the time of actual physical payment. He therefore, set aside the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held against appellant on both points and restored ITO order

anchor.surface_text: On appeals against the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, both by the appellant and the Income-tax Officer the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Calcutta Bench, held against the appellant on both the points and restored the order of the Income-tax Officer.

facts.text: Appellant paid the amount on or about April 16, 1953 to avoid recovery proceedings

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence of the said decision and to save itself from the companysequences of a drastic recovery proceeding the appellant paid the amount on or about April 16, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant requested foreign company to reimburse the tax paid on its behalf

anchor.surface_text: However, the appellant simultaneously took up the matter with the foreign companypany and requested the companypany to reimburse the appellant in the matter of the tax paid on behalf of the foreign companypany.

facts.text: Foreign company repudiated its liability to pay the tax

anchor.surface_text: The foreign companypany, however, repudiated its liability to pay the tax.

facts.text: Appellant claimed deduction of Rs. 1,24,199 paid to Government as extra business expenditure under section 10(2)(xv) for assessment year 1954-55

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, as a matter of companymercial accidence and necessity the appellant treated the sum of Rs. 1, 24, 199 odd paid to Government as an extra expenditure incurred in its business and claimed a deduction in respect thereof under section 10 2  xv  of the Act in the assessment proceedings for the year 1954-55.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the claim for deduction

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companycerned disallowed the claim.

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner was unsuccessful

anchor.surface_text: There was an unsuccessful appeal to the Appellate Assistance Commissioner.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal by order dated May 29, 1956 disallowed the claim

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was then taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and by the order companyplained of, namely, the order dated May 29, 1956, the Tribunal

facts.text: Tribunal rejected application under section 66(1) for reference to High Court

anchor.surface_text: the Tribunal under section 66 1  of the Act to make a reference to the High Court on the question as to whether the sum of Rs. 1, 24, 199.3 nP. incurred by the appellant during the relevant accounting year was deductible under section 10 2  xv  of the Act. The Tribunal rejected the application on the ground that the question did number arise from the order of the Tribunal.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta rejected appellant's application under section 66(2)

arguments.claim: Special leave to appeal from Tribunal order dated May 29, 1956 under Article 136 was not properly granted and appellant not entitled to invoke Article 136 discretion as did not challenge subsequent orders of Board and High Court under section 66

anchor.surface_text: The question which has arisen in this appeal by way of a preliminary objection is whether in the circumstances set out above, special leave to appeal from the decision of the Tribunal dated May 29, 1956, was properly given under article 136 of the Constitution and whether the appellant is entitled to ask this court to exercise its discretion under the said article when it did number move against the subsequent orders of the Board and the High Court under section 66 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Following decision in similar Civil Appeals Nos. 170-172 of 1959

arguments.claim: Special leave not properly granted and appellant not entitled to Article 136 as bypassed subsequent orders under section 66

anchor.surface_text: This question fell for companysideration in very similar circumstances in Civil Appeals Nos. 170-172 of 1959 in which we have delivered judgment to-day. As a matter of fact this appeal was heard along with Civil Appeals Nos. 170-172 of 1959 and full arguments were heard from companynsel for both sides. Following the decision in Civil Appeals Nos. 170-172 of 1959 we hold that special leave to appeal from the decision of the Tribunal dated May 29, 1956, was number properly granted in this case and the appellant is number entitled to ask us to exercise our power under article 136 of the companystitution when it did number move against the subsequent orders of the Board and the High Court.
